thread.title: To Dim or Not to Dim? Honoring Broadway’s Dead
thread.title_full: To Dim or Not to Dim? Honoring Broadway’s Dead - WSJ

author: Pia Catton
title: To Dim or Not to Dim? Honoring Broadway’s Dead
text:
0 COMMENTS For at least 50 years, New York has honored the passing of lifelong theater-industry participants by briefly dimming the lights of Broadway marquees. But in the social-media era, the decision over whose legacy merits the tradition is kicking up painful public controversy.
Fans and friends of the late comedian Joan Rivers rallied last year in response to the initial announcement—later reversed—that the lights wouldn’t be dimmed for her.
The issue surfaced again after the death Saturday of 21-year-old Kyle Jean-Baptiste, who in July became the youngest actor and first black man to play the lead role of Jean Valjean on Broadway in “Les Misérables.” This month, he was slated to join the cast of his second show, the coming revival of “The Color Purple.”
To commemorate the young performer, only the Imperial Theatre, home to “Les Miz,” was scheduled to have its marquee dimmed Tuesday night, a move that led friends and supporters to raise opposition on Facebook FB -2.46 % and Twitter TWTR -2.73 % directed at the arbiter of lights: the Broadway League, the industry’s national trade association.
“The Broadway League got it wrong here,” said April Reign, who posted about the issue and serves as managing editor of Broadway Black, a digital platform that notes the achievements of African-Americans onstage and off. “People around the world are discussing this. It’s not just the Broadway enthusiasts.”
According to the League’s president, Charlotte St. Martin, a 10-person committee of the 800-member group makes the choice.
“They are industry people who are following 50 years of tradition,” said Ms. St. Martin, adding that the committee’s individual members aren’t disclosed to prevent lobbying. “It is a very thoughtful group of people.”
The criteria, she said, can be gleaned from past recipients of the tribute.
“You just have to look at the people who have been honored, and you see that it by no means includes everybody,” she said. “It’s people who have spent a lifetime in the theater.”
In 2015, four people so far have been honored: Producer and agent Samuel “Biff” Liff, who died at age 96; actor Theodore Bikel, age 91; actor-director Roger Rees, age 71, who had just starred in the 2015 musical “The Visit”; and actor-director Gene Saks, age 93.
For these and others, the lights have typically been turned down for one minute shortly before an evening show, which in most cases precludes the cast from participating while they prepare.
ENLARGE Kyle Jean-Baptiste. Photo: The Les Misérables Company For Mr. Jean-Baptiste, however, the Imperial’s lights were scheduled to dim at 10:15 p.m. Tuesday, allowing the cast and crew who knew him to gather after the show.
Additionally, with the arrival of marquees outfitted with LED lights, an illuminated picture of the deceased can be posted.
“It is enhanced enormously by having the photo,” said Bill Evans, director of media relations for the Shubert Organization, which owns the Imperial. “Families gather. Fans can look at it.”
While these small changes have evolved the tradition, it is the digital world that has turned what was once an industry rite into a viral flash-point for controversy.
“The advent of social media has changed the conversation,” said Ms. St. Martin.
During the controversy over Joan Rivers, supporters circulated the label #Dim4Joan on Twitter, a move that was adapted to #Dim4Kyle this week.
In Ms. Reign’s view, the criteria for receiving the honor should be broader: “It is your impact on the community, not your age or longevity.”
Ms. St. Martin said a similar tension develops in the months leading up to Broadway’s season honors in the Tony Awards broadcast, when people want their loved ones included in the memorial segment.
“It is emotional,” said Ms. St. Martin. “People love their people, and I understand.”
Write to Pia Catton at pia.catton@wsj.com
